results.title: Janus. Eps 21 and 22: Demands with menaces. Fit to plead
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 21 and 22 of the television series Janus. “Demands with menaces” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) finds Peter Faithful in the hot seat again. Rhonda Hennessey’s (Victoria Eagger) husband, Darren Mack (Nique Needles) is to stand trial at a committal hearing for attempted extortion on a fellow inmate at Pentridge. Allegations are made about Peter Faithful’s involvement with the victim, Zoglin (Raj Sidhu) at the police interview and Faithful offering support to Zoglin in a bail application. Michael Kidd argues on the premise of the Hennessey connection, that Darren Mack is part of the Hennessey family and subsequently a target for Peter Faithful’s ongoing investigation into the Hennessey’s. “Fit to plead” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) follows two separate court scenarios. One involving Darren Mack attending his sentencing hearing and the other, an Aboriginal prisoner, Ray Crundall (David Ngoombujarra) being tried for assault. Defence Counsellor, Kathy Tainsh (Glenda Linscott) finds herself fighting the system for justice and understanding on behalf of her Aboriginal client, and Darren Mack decides to fight the system himself, sacking his Defence Counsellor and going it alone. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Steve Hardman, Tracy Mann, and Alex Scott.

results.title: Janus. Eps 19 and 20: Confess and avoid. A Prima facie case
results.creator_credit: Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 19 and 20 of the television series Janus. “Confess and avoid” (48 mins) (directed by Robert Klenner) literally means confess to the lesser charges and hopefully avoid the serious charge. Michael Kidd has not lost a case in eight years but doubts start to set in when he finds himself defending a young law student, Ian Bisley (Richard Sutherland) who has been charged with culpable driving. Jenny Hanson (Jane Menelaus) as representative for the Crown Prosecution at the same time, is not looking forward to doing battle with the formidable Michael Kidd. “A Prima facie case” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Witnesses are called to give evidence at the commital hearing into Steve Hennessey’s death. Allegations are being made that Peter Faithful covered up for his mates and conflicting versions by the witnesses as to whether Steve Hennessey was armed, only complicates matters further. Peter Faithful decides to confront Michael Kidd’s allegations of persecution and corruption by taking the witness stand. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Tamsin West, David Bradshaw and Steve Vidler.

results.title: Janus. Eps 17 and 18: Right to remain silent. My learned friend, Mr Hennessey
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 17 and 18 of the television series Janus. “Right to remain silent” (51 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). The internal investigation into the shooting of Steve Hennessey continues. Meantime, Roz Breen (Jeanette Cronin) who has been charged with smuggling drugs into prison, decides to fight the case. Her defence is “duress”, caused by intimidation and fear of the Hennessey family. Although Steve is dead, the drug trafficking connection still lives on. “My learned friend, Mr Hennessey” (52 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) shows Mal Hennessey (Brett Swain) in a somewhat different light to the usual cold, indifferent violent person that he can be, as he defends himself in a commital hearing on a charge of “Breach of prison” relating to his escape from the Police Van. With Shirl Hennessey still in Fairlea and no money to pay Michael Kidd to defend him, Mal has to take on the system. And take on the system he does, much to Vic Manoulis’s frustration and Peter Faithful’s growing concern. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Leverne McDonnell, Simon Chilvers, Paul Gleeson.

results.title: Janus. Eps 15 and 16: Suicide by cop. Intent to permanently deprive
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 15 and 16 of the television series Janus. “Suicide by cop” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods). Steve Hennnessey is dead and Peter Faithful and his men in the Tactical Response Squad, particularly Danny (Steve Vidler), are now under investigation by the Homicide Squad. Matters become further complicated when new evidence is brought to light implicating both Peter and Danny not following police procedures at the scene of the crime. Extra pressure is also put on Danny when he takes the stand as an informant for a 2 year-old assault case which Tina Bertrum (Tracy Mann) is prosecuting. “Intent to permanently deprive” (49 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Shirl Hennessey is charged with shop-lifting and in possession of a lighter-pistol and appears to want to go down for the crime, much to the bewilderment of Michael Kidd, her Defence Counsellor. Vic Manoulis finds himself involved with a disturbing child abuse murder case. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Robert Wallace, John Arnold and Frank Gallacher.

results.title: Janus. Eps 13 and 14: Burden of proof. A Lawful apprehension
results.creator_credit: Bill Hughes, Mandy Smith and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 13 and 14 of the television series Janus. “Burden of proof” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) finds the jury in a quandry - who do they believe, Dale Cassidy’s girlfriend Simone, or Steve Hennessey’s defacto wife Kirsty. Peter Faithful is put under fire on the witness stand by Michael Kidd with the suggestion that “revenge” on the Hennessey family for the murder of the two police officers at the Vic Bank armed robbery had become an obsession and that Faithful would go to any lengths to get a conviction. Pressure is also being put on Mal’s ex-girlfriend Sandy to tell the truth about the night of the murder of Patrick Clancy or face perjury. “A Lawful apprehension” (51 mins) (directed by Bill Hughes and Mandy Smith). On the strength of Sandy’s signed statement, Mal is arrested and bail application refused. The Hennessey family, Shirl, Steve and Kirsty, remain under surveillance. Peter Faithful still trying to do a deal with Steve Hennessey to dob his brother Mal in, in exchange for a new start for him and Kirsty under police protection. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Brett Swain, Leon Teague, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Pepe Trevor, Louise Siversen and Jane Menelaus.

results.title: Janus. Eps 11 and 12: Without prejudice. Improper influences
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 11 and 12 of the television series Janus. “Without prejudice” (50 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) gives an insight to jury selection procedures and the workings of a jury during a trial. Steve Hennessey (Leon Teague) and Darren Mack (Nique Needles) are finally being tried for “trafficking of drugs of dependence” with Dale Cassidy (previously a Prosecution witness at the commital hearing) now appearing as the main witness for the Prosecution. Peter Faithful and Rob Griffin are slowly mounting evidence against Mal Hennessey for the murder of Patrick Clancy. “Improper influences” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Judge Grossman (Denis Moore) is determined to see the Steve Hennessey drug trial through, despite growing concern about his health. Defence’s case focuses on the questionable quality of the police surveillance video-tape of the drug deal. Peter Faithful’s unrelenting pursuit of evidence to get Mal Hennessey for murder leads him to Mal’s ex-girlfriend who is serving time in Fairlea Women’s Prison. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Grant Piro, Sheryl Munks, Damian Foley, Greg Fleet and Pepe Trevor.

results.title: Janus. Eps 09 and 10: A Mischievous offence. A Familiar utterance
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 9 and 10 of the television series Janus. “A Mischievous offence” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) has the eccentric DPP Prosecutor Clyde Martin (Douglas Hedge) at his witty best in the court room scene, playing to the jury, annoying the Defence and humoring the witnesses. The case being handled is a horse ring-in trial and the star witness, an 8 year-old boy. Steve Hennessey is still missing and Peter Faithful offers to do a deal with Kenny Hardy (being held for the armed bank robbery) in exchange for information leading to Steve’s whereabouts. “A Familiar utterance” (50 mins) (directed by Michael Carson). The irony of it all - Michael Kidd, the Hennessey’s barrister, is asked to defend two police (formerly of the Drug Squad) who have been charged with assaulting a bouncer in a night club. Rob Griffin, following a tip off from Prosecutor Clyde Martin, links up with Peter Faithful in tracking down a brief of a 10 year old unsolved murder of Patrick Clancy, best mate of Mal Hennessey. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Jack Finsterer, Elizabeth Welch, Tracy Mann, Jane Menelaus, Michael Edward-Stevens, Damian Foley and David Cotter.

results.title: Janus. Eps 07 and 08: Without consent. Fail to appear
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 7 and 8 of the television series Janus. “Without consent” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) sees Rob Griffin (Felix Nobis) taking a leading role for the Prosecution in a child sexual abuse case. Two young adult sisters claim that they were sexually abused as children by their uncle and are prepared to come to the stand and give evidence. In the meantime, Michael Kidd (Chris Haywood) files for a bail application for Steve Hennessey (Leon Teague) who is in remand on a drug trafficking charge. “Fail to appear” (51 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). The night before his court case, Steve Hennessey is charged and taken into custody by the Armed Robbery Squad for an Armaguard robbery. Conflict arises between Peter Faithful (Tactical Response Squad) and the Armed Robbery Squad over territorial rights to Steve Hennessey. Tina (Tracy Mann) faces an uphill battle prosecuting for a client, George Provis (John Paisley), who cannot remember how he was viciously assaulted at a shelter for homeless men. George is an alcoholic who suffers wandering thoughts and memory lapses. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Robyn Butler, Tamara Saulwick, Brandon Burke, Aidan Fennessey.

results.title: Janus. Eps 05 and 06: Judgement amongst short men. Reckless indifference
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 5 and 6 of the television series Janus. “Judgement amongst short men” (47 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) focuses on two court cases, the first one relating to a rape case involving a prostitute and a questionably lenient sentence given to the rapist and the other case, Rhonda Hennessey standing accused for attempting to pervert the course of justice. Rhonda Hennessey’s trial follows on from her attempts to threaten Kirsty Nichols (Steve Hennessey’s pregnant girlfriend) when Kirsty, turned police informant, was to give evidence against the Hennessey family. “Reckless indifference” (47 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) revolves around the youngest son of the Hennessey family, Shane Hennessey (Jonathan Kernutt) and his refusal after being charged with attempted murder, theft of a stolen vehicle, reckless conduct etc to admit his identity to the police or to the Court. Rather than being afraid of police reaction, Shane is far more concerned and frightened of his brother Mal. He chooses to face the charges alone, rather than go to his family for help. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Louise Siversen, Belinda McClory, Leverne McDonnell, Jane Menelaus, Frank Magree, Ezra Bix and Jonathan Kernutt.

results.title: Janus. Eps 03 and 04: Not on the merits. A Rare crushing reversal
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Kate Woods, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 3 and 4 of the television series Janus. “Not on the merits” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) continues on the story of the Hennessey’s and police endeavours to convict, in particular, Mal Hennessey. After a protracted police surveillance of Mal Hennnessey, and using a police undercover operant, Peter Faithful and his squad finally video a drug deal, arresting Mal Hennessey and Kirsty Nichols, Steve Hennessey’s girlfriend. Kirsty, under pressure by the police, turns informant/witness for the prosecution. “A Rare crushing reversal” (51 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney) involves once again another arrest of Mal and Steve Hennessey and Darren Mack on drug charges. However Peter Faithful’s witness, Dale Cassidy (Grant Piro), a drug addict who was supplied by the Hennessey’s and who the police offered to put under the witness protection scheme in exchange for information finds that it’s not so easy “dobbing in a mate”. Even more so when he is faced with the continual barrage from the Defence Counsellor, Michael Kidd (Chris Haywood). Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Louise Siversen, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Brett Swain.
